column11: definition
AL IAO:0000115@en

column12: A sample that is comprised predominately of living (or decomposing) material; for use when more specific information on composition of sample is not provided.

column11: A material entity that has a plasma membrane and results from cellular division.
An organismal grouping baised on how a living entity acquires or generates food and energy from a living, dead, or non-living entity.
column13: In ECOCORE these are direct subclasses to organism OBI:0100026, we could do that here if desired.
ECOCORE has more subclasses that could be imported.

column11: An organism that obtains carbon for growth and development by a combination of heterotrophy (metabolizing biogenic organic compounds derived from living or dead material ) and autotrophy (capable of incorporating inorganic carbon into its biomass).
The classification groups of biological organisms based on shared characteristics that are not part of a rigorous taxonomic framework.
Classification by planktonic size range
Plankton classification by size range: <0.2 um (viruses).
Plankton classification by size range: 0.2-2.0 um (bacteria, very small Eukaryotes).
Plankton classification by size range: 2-20 um (diatoms, dinoflagellates, protozoa).
Plankton classification by size range: 20-200 um (diatoms, dinoflagellates, protozoa, copepod nauplii, etc.).
Plankton classification by size range: 0.2-20 mm (mostly zooplankton).
Plankton classification by size range: 2-20 cm.
Plankton classification by general functional group.
Plankton consisting of small animals and the immature stages of larger animals.
Plankton consisting of small (mainly microscopic) photosynthetic organisms.
Plankton consisting of single-celled protozoa with cilia.
The natural language (non-taxonomic) name of the type of organism that is the subject of a given investigation, study and/or specimen.
A limbless cold-blooded vertebrate animal with gills and fins and living wholly in water.
An organism capable of nitrogen fixation (conversion of atmospheric dinitrogen into bioavailable forms).
An organism which uses heterocycts for nitrogen fixation (conversion of atmospheric dinitrogen into bioavailable forms).
The classification groups of biological organisms based on shared characteristics.
The relative level of a group of organisms in a taxonomic hierarchy.
A taxonomic rank which is the broadest unit of classification.
A taxonomic rank which is classified above phylum and below domain.
A taxonomic rank which is classified above class and below kingdom.
A taxonomic rank which is classified above order and below phylum.
A taxonomic rank which is classified above family and below class.
A taxonomic rank which is classified above genus and below order.
A taxonomic rank which is classified above species and below family.
A taxonomic rank which is most basic or specific unit of classification.
Taxonomic classification of organisms as described by unique identifiers within the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS) taxonomic classification database.
column13: Future direction to make OBO compliant IDs for WoRMS

column11: Taxonomic classification of organisms as described by unique identifiers within the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) taxonomy database.
column13: Cross listed in external repositories? Perhaps better to import relevant NCBITaxon subclasses and add them here.
